If left untreated, hypertension can lead to serious health problems like heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, and vision loss.

knowledge: Colonoscopy Colonoscopy  A colonoscopy is an outpatient procedure that examines the large intestine (colon) and rectum.  It's commonly used to screen for colon cancer and to investigate symptoms like abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and changes in bowel habits.  During a colonoscopy, a long, flexible tube with a camera on the end is inserted through the rectum and guided through the colon.  The camera sends images to a monitor, which allows the doctor to examine the lining of the colon.  If any abnormalities are found, the doctor can take tissue samples or remove polyps.  A colonoscopy typically takes 30 - 60 minutes and requires some preparation beforehand, like a special diet and bowel prep.  Afterward, you may experience bloating, gas, or cramping, but these symptoms should go away in a day. Colonoscopy Colonoscopy

knowledge: Heart disease Heart disease  Coronary artery disease is the most common type of heart disease.  It develops when cholesterol-containing deposits (plaques) build up in your coronary arteries.  These deposits can narrow your arteries and restrict blood flow to your heart.
